snippet: Officials say a deal involving the European Central Bank’s holdings of Greek bonds could bridge a crucial financing gap and clear the way for the next bailout.
abstract: European Central Bank may forgo future profits on its Greek bonds as part of a deal to fill a financial hole that has been obstructing a second bailout for Greece; issue of how to fill gap must be resolved before Greece can qualify for a second bailout, expected to total roughly 130 billion euros ($170 billion).

byline.original: By STEPHEN CASTLE and JACK EWING
byline.contributor: Stephen Castle reported from Brussels and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt. Niki Kitsantonis contributed reporting from Athens.

lead_paragraph: Officials say a deal involving the European Central Bank’s holdings of Greek bonds could bridge a crucial financing gap and clear the way for the next bailout.

headline.main: In Talks on Greek Bailout, Eyes Turn to Central Bank
